item.title: [DATAMONGO-392] Updating an object does not write type information for objects to be updated
item.description:
I'm using quite complex domain model, that consist of instantiable domain classes as well as of abstract ones. I used 1.0.0.M5 version, and the type information (under _class key) was stored with object when it was necessary to be able to read it from database later. That worked perfectly for me till my upgrade to 1.0.0.RELEASE version that broke my application as it saves the objects without type information and later it is impossible to read it back to java model.

What I found is that MappingMongoConverter.writeInternal(...) method that in turn calls addCustomTypeIfNecessary(...) (line 330) which puts type information into DBObject. During execution of convertToMongoType(...) (at line 851) removeTypeInfoRecursively(...) is called which clears type data saved earlier under _class key. I had to comment out this call in order to

The first point is that there is a contradiction: why to save type information to DBObject if it is later removed by other method? The second point is that there should be a way to persist the type information inferred from runtime along the persisted object and not just the class definition.

First of all we have to make sure we discuss a single item at once. Your headline states two issues actually and we seem to discuss the latter. In how far is the first statement (not persisting properties from abstract base classes) related to this one. If it's not, would you mind to open another ticket and post code samples there?

First, the type information written to the document is taken from the value passed in. It's done in write(…) (actually I wonder what other type information we could use for top level types, if not the one of the value). The only situation we potentially pass in slightly different information is when dealing with collections or maps. In this case the component/value type might be less concrete than the value and we uses that case to only write additional type information to the store in case it's necessary.

Regarding the convertToMongoType(…) method you're right in terms of the method actually is removing type information but it is never actually called from a write(…) method. So a DBObject created by calling write(…) will contain type information (if the default TypeMapper setup is used).

The convertToMongoType(…) actually exists for a very important reason: when executing Query objects or binding repository parameters we actually must not had an object with the type information to the actual query as this would drop results that might not carry the type information. E.g. assume you have a document with a property of address containing a nested Address document that does not contain type information. If you now create a query using new Query(new Criteria("address").is(address)) and we'd convert the address value to match against using MappingMongoConverter.write(…) we'd never get any result back as the document residing in the store does not have the type information and thus doesn't match. So for query repository parameter massaging we actually need document representation of the object without the type information added.

So coming back to the original issue. How do your domain classes look like. What does the code look like trying to persist the object, what does the data look like that gets written? What do the objects look like when being read from the store again?

I've also been affected by this issue. I did a little bit of research on the problem and came to this conclusion: the convertToMongoType(Object) method doesn't have enough information about the top-level Java type to determine if the type information should be removed.

Allow me to explain how I've come to this conclusion. First, it's helpful to understand what happens in the MongoTemplate.insert(Object) method. It calls MappingMongoConverter.writeInternal(Object, DBObject, TypeInformation<?>) to convert a Java object into a Mongo DBObject. At the end of this method, the MappingMongoConverter.addCustomTypeKeyIfNecessary(TypeInformation<?> type, Object value, DBObject dbObject) method is called. This method determines if the class type should be written to the DBObject. It does this using the TypeInformation<?> object passed in to determine if the type of the input value is the same as the type of the specified object. This is best understood by looking at an example:

public interface Model { 
}
 
 
 
class ModelA extends Model {
 
  public String value;
 
}
 
 
 
class Document {
 
  @Id
 
  public String id;
 
  public Model model;
 
}
 
 
 
class App {
 
  MongoOperations mongoOps = ...;
 
  void create() {
 
    Document doc = new Document();
 
    doc.model = new ModelA(...);
 
    mongoOps.insert(doc);
 
  }
 
}

In this example, the value object would have type ModelA, but the actual type of model in Document is Model. Thus, addCustomTypeKeyIfNecessary adds the type class into the DBObject.

Returning to the matter at hand: when update is called, the actual update operation is converted into a Mongo DBObject describing the update. Going back to the example above, if we added the following method to App:

  public void update(String documentId) {
 
    mongoOps.updateFirst(new Query(where("id").is(documentId),
 
      new Update().set("model", new ModelA("new value")),
 
      Document.class);
 
  }

the Mongo DBObject would look like:

{ "$set" : { "model" : { "value" : "new value" } } }

Of course, you'll notice the missing _class attribute of model. This is due to the removeTypeInfoRecursively method, as discussed in the prior comments.

It seems to me that what we would like to have is something similar to what happens in an insert, where we determine if we need to add the class type if the updated object type doesn't match the actual type, e.g. ModelA doesn't match Model. However, we no longer have the TypeInformation<?> object to make this determination. This is how I came to the conclusion that there is not enough information available on an update.

It may be a non-trivial matter to add this in. It would require more extensive parsing of the update, e.g. determining that the "id" string in the above example refers to Document.id.

It does seem to me that the removal of the removeTypeInfoRecursively call would fix the problem, but would have the additional side-effect of adding the class type information to portions of the document that do not require it. To slightly complicate matter further, the convertToMongoType method is called by other callers.

I apologize for the verbosity of this comment. I hope that it elucidates the issue and leads to a fix in the near future.

Thanks,
Evan
